What is Dr. Neelan Thiruchelvam's view on judiciary?

According to Dr. Neelan Thiruchelvam: “The future of the judiciary as the custodian of the public conscience in strife ridden Sri Lanka does not rest in abstract constitutional principles or arrangements. It depends on the quality of those who assume the judicial mantle and their capacity to be morally outraged by injustice and discriminatory practices and to draw on the armoury of their legal power to redress their grievances.”
What is the concurrent list in the 13th Amendment?

According to 13th Amendment to the Constitution (1987), Article 154G(5), 154G(6), 154G(9): Concurrent List [Article 154G (5)] Both the Parliament and the Provincial council can legislate after consultations (with each other). [Article 154G (6)] In the case of any conflict between Provincial Statute and an Act of Parliament, the Act prevails and the Provincial statute shall be void to the extent of inconsistency. [Article 154G (9)] If the Law existed prior to the 13th Amendment, this Law remains suspended and inoperative within the province so long as the statute id in force unless the Parliament decides contrary by resolution. After which the Act is valid
Can torture be denied to criminals?

According to Second Republican Constitution of Sri Lanka (1978), Article 11: It further states that this FR cannot be denied/ prohibited even if the applicant is a hardcore criminal who is wanted by law.
What is the punishment for electronic drug adulteration facilitation?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 276A - Facilitation of drug adulteration by electronic means.: Section 276A punishes electronic facilitation of drug adulteration with imprisonment up to six months or fine, or both.
What is the punishment for electronic claim false facilitation?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 209C - Facilitation of claim false by electronic means.: Section 209C punishes electronic facilitation of claim false with imprisonment up to two years and fine.
What was Dudley Senanayake's view on the presidential system for Sri Lanka?

According to Dudley Senanayake (1971): Dudley Senanayake, the esteemed colleague of JR Jayewardene and R Premadasa both, had the following prophetic statement to make, in 1971, ‘The Presidential system has worked in the United States where it was the result of a special historic situation. It worked in France for similar reasons. But, for Ceylon, it would be disastrous. It would create as tradition of Caesarism. It would concentrate power in a leader and undermine parliament and the structure of the political parties. In American and France it has worked, but generally it is a system for an Nkrumah or a Nasser, not for a free democracy.’
What is sale of printed or engraved substance containing defamatory matter in the Sri Lanka Penal Code?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 486: Whoever sells or offers for sale any printed or engraved substance containing defamatory matter, knowing that it contains such matter, shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
What is the punishment for voluntarily causing hurt to extort confession?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 330 - Voluntarily causing hurt to extort confession, or to compel restoration of property.: Section 330 punishes hurt to extort confession with imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
What is the punishment for giving false information to court?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 203 - Giving false information respecting offence committed.: Section 203 punishes false information to court with imprisonment up to two years or fine, or both.
What are the maximum and minimum punishments for printing defamatory matter of President under the Penal Code?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 482A - Printing or engraving matter known to be defamatory of President.: Section 482A prescribes simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both. No minimum term.
What is the punishment for sexual exploitation of children?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 360E - Sexual exploitation of children.: Section 360E punishes sexual exploitation of children with imprisonment not less than five years and not exceeding twenty years, and fine.
What are the maximum and minimum punishments for conspiracy to commit offence punishable with death under the Penal Code?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 111 - Conspiracy to commit offences punishable by section 118.: Section 111 punishes conspiracy to wage war with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine. No minimum term.
Restrict immunity?

According to Second Republican Constitution of Sri Lanka (1978): It has been argued that immunity should be restricted to the official and legitimate activities of the President enabling the Courts to decide the issue of immunity on a case-by-case basis. This is necessary in a republic where the sovereignty resides with the people.
What are the maximum and minimum punishments for waging war against the Republic under the Penal Code?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 118 - Waging or attempting to wage war against the Republic.: Section 118 provides for death, or imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to twenty years, and shall forfeit all property. Minimum is the alternative sentence.
How is using a forged document as genuine defined in the Sri Lanka Penal Code?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 471: Whoever fraudulently or dishonestly uses as genuine any document which he knows or has reason to believe to be a forged document, shall be punished in the same manner as if he had forged such document.
Chief of party?
According to Second Republican Constitution of Sri Lanka (1978): Generally, he would nearly always be the chief of his political party (consider the modern SLPP in this context).
What is good faith imputation on character for protection of interests in the Sri Lanka Penal Code?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 479, Ninth Exception: It is not defamation to make an imputation on the character of another, provided that the imputation be made in good faith for the protection of the interests of the person making it, or of any other person, or for the public good.
Responsible to parliament?

According to Second Republican Constitution of Sri Lanka (1978), Article 42: As per Article 42, the President is responsible to the Parliament for the due exercise, performance and discharge of his powers.
Describe the Donoughmore Constitution in Sri Lanka's constitutional development.

Created by the Donoughmore Commission, served Sri Lanka (Ceylon) from 1931 to 1947. It was a significant development as it was the only constitution in the British Empire enabling general elections with adult universal suffrage.
What is the punishment for electronic robbery facilitation?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 380A - Facilitation of robbery by electronic means.: Section 380A punishes electronic facilitation of robbery with rigorous imprisonment up to ten years and fine.
What are the maximum and minimum punishments for theft under the Penal Code?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 367 - Punishment for theft.: Section 367 prescribes imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both. No minimum term.
What is the punishment for assisting escape of prisoner of war?
According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 127 - Assisting escape of prisoner of war.: Section 127 punishes assisting prisoner of war escape with imprisonment up to ten years and fine.
What is the punishment for electronic found property retention facilitation?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 368C - Facilitation of found property retention by electronic means.: Section 368C punishes electronic facilitation of found property retention with imprisonment up to one year or fine, or both.
What are the maximum and minimum punishments for wrongful confinement under the Penal Code?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 330 - Punishment for wrongful confinement.: Section 330 punishes with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine up to one thousand rupees, or with both. No minimum punishment.
Can govern without house confidence?
According to Second Republican Constitution of Sri Lanka (1978): In practical terms, he can govern without the consent or continued confidence of the House.
What is the punishment for counterfeiting government stamps?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 242 - Counterfeiting of any stamp issued by Government for purpose of revenue.: Section 242 punishes counterfeiting revenue stamps with imprisonment up to fifteen years and fine.
What are the maximum and minimum punishments for voluntarily causing grievous hurt under the Penal Code?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 319 - Punishment for voluntarily causing grievous hurt.: Section 319 punishes voluntarily causing grievous hurt with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine. No explicit minimum term is specified.
What are the maximum and minimum punishments for lurking house-trespass by night under the Penal Code?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 442 - Lurking house-trespass by night.: Section 442 punishes with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine. No minimum term.
Examples of prerogative?
According to Indo-Lanka Accord (1987); Ceasefire Agreement (2002): Writers cite the example of the President entering into the Indo Lanka Accord and the ceasefire Agreement with the LTTE in 2002.
What are fundamental rights in terrorism?

According to Declaration on Upholding Human Rights and the Rule of Law in Combating Terrorism: In the implementation of counter- terrorism measures, states must respect and safeguard fundamental rights and freedoms including freedom of expression , religion, conscience or belief association and assembly and the peaceful pursuit of the right to self determination as well as the right to privacy. All restrictions on fundamental rights and freedoms must be necessary and proportionate.
Motion notice?

According to Second Republican Constitution of Sri Lanka (1978): Any member of Parliament may give notice of a motion alleging that the President is permanently incapable of discharging the functions of his office by reason of mental or physical infirmity or that he has been guilty on one of the following five grounds: Intentional violation of the Constitution. Treason. Bribery. Misconduct or corruption, involving the abuse of powers in his office. Any offence under any law, involving moral turpitude, and setting out full particulars of the allegation or allegations made and seeking an inquiry and report thereon by the Supreme Court.
What is the punishment for public servant taking gratification other than legal remuneration?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 161 - Public servant taking gratification other than legal remuneration in respect of an official act.: Section 161 punishes public servant taking illegal gratification with imprisonment up to three years or fine, or both.
What is the punishment for adulteration of food or drink intended for sale?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 272 - Adulteration of food or drink intended for sale.: Section 272 punishes adulteration of food or drink with noxious substance with imprisonment up to six months or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.
How is enticing or taking away a married woman defined in the Sri Lanka Penal Code?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 496: Whoever takes or entices away any woman who is and whom he knows or has reason to believe to be the wife of any other man, from that man, without the consent of such man, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
What attending parliament?

According to Second Republican Constitution of Sri Lanka (1978), Article 32(3); 18th Amendment (2010): As per Article 32 (3) the President by virtue of his office must attend Parliament every three months. This was brought about by the 18th amendment. However, he may not vote, in spite of having all the other rights and privileges of parliamentarians.
What is Dicey's second meaning of rule of law?

According to Dicey: Everyman, whatever his rank or condition, is subject to the ordinary law of the state and amendable to the Jurisdiction of the ordinary tribunals. This gives the idea that every man is equal before the law. However, certain public citizens have received certain privileges of immunity from the legal process. (Ex: President of the Republic, Ambassadors, Judges) There is a need for special tribunals and courts in a modern state provided they are independent.
What is the punishment for house-trespass?
According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 434 - Punishment for house-trespass.: Section 434 punishes house-trespass with imprisonment up to one year or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.
What are the maximum and minimum punishments for criminal intimidation under the Penal Code?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 483 - Criminal intimidation.: Section 483 provides for simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both. If the threat is to cause death or grievous hurt, the term may extend to seven years. No minimum term.
What after dissolution timing?

According to Second Republican Constitution of Sri Lanka (1978): After the dissolution of Parliament, in accordance with the above, the President shall a fix a date for the election and shall summon the fresh parliament not less than 3 months from the date of dissolution.
What are the maximum and minimum punishments for undue influence at elections under the Penal Code?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 169B - Undue influence at elections.: Section 169B punishes with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both. No minimum punishment.
What are the maximum and minimum punishments for mischief under the Penal Code?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 406 - Mischief.: Section 406 prescribes imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three months, or with fine, or with both. For damage over fifty rupees (Section 410), up to two years. No minimum.
What are the maximum and minimum punishments for causing hurt endangering life under the Penal Code?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 313 - Causing hurt by act endangering life.: Section 313 punishes with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to five years, or with fine, or with both. No minimum punishment.
Procedure lengthy?

According to Second Republican Constitution of Sri Lanka (1978): The procedure involves moving from the Parliament to the SC, and then back again to Parliament. The first president to face an impeachment process was President R. Premadasa in 1992. In reality the procedure is lengthy and requires extraordinary majorities, making it virtually impossible to carry it through.
What is the punishment for cheating and dishonestly inducing delivery of property?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 420 - Cheating and dishonestly inducing delivery of property.: Section 420 punishes cheating inducing property delivery with imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
What is the punishment for electronic criminal intimidation facilitation?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 486A - Facilitation of criminal intimidation by electronic means.: Section 486A punishes electronic facilitation of intimidation with imprisonment up to two years or fine, or both.
Describe the nature of constitutional law.

The Constitutional law of a state has been defined as “the law relating to the constitution of a state”. The definition is wide enough to include the study of matters that are of constitutional importance to a country, such as the historical, political and philosophical foundations of the constitution.
How is punishment for defamation defined in the Sri Lanka Penal Code?
According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 484: Whoever defames another shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
How is attempt to murder defined under the Sri Lanka Penal Code?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 299: Whoever attempts to commit murder, and in such attempt does any act under such circumstances that if he by that act caused death he would be guilty of murder, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine; and if hurt is caused to any person thereby, the offender shall be liable either to imprisonment for life or to such punishment as is hereinbefore mentioned.
What are the maximum and minimum punishments for incest under the Penal Code?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 364 - Incest.: Section 364 prescribes rigorous imprisonment for a term not less than seven years and not exceeding twenty years, and shall also be liable to fine.
Describe self-sufficiency in autochthonous constitutions.

Self Sufficiency: Prof. K.C. Whear described it as 'For some members of the common wealth it is not enough to be able to say that they enjoy the system of government which is in no way subordinate to the government of the United Kingdom. They wish to say that their constitution has the force of law.' This means that an autochthonous constitution is ‘born in its country’ and not granted by any other state. The first Republican Constitution of Sri Lanka (1972) is an example for a self sufficient constitution.
What are the maximum and minimum punishments for omission to assist public servant under the Penal Code?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 184 - Omission to assist public servant when bound by law.: Section 184 prescribes simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to one month, or with fine up to fifty rupees, or with both. No minimum punishment.
What are the maximum and minimum punishments for institution of criminal proceeding based on false charge under the Penal Code?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 206 - Institution of criminal proceeding based on false charge.: Section 206 punishes with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both; up to seven years if capital. No minimum punishment.
Was referendum required in 1972?
According to First Republican Constitution of Sri Lanka (1972): There were no provisions for the requirement of a referendum.
What are the maximum and minimum punishments for lurking house-trespass to commit imprisonable offence under the Penal Code?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 434 - Lurking house-trespass or house-breaking to commit imprisonable offence.: Section 434 provides for imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and fine. No minimum punishment.
What are the maximum and minimum punishments for bribery to influence a public servant under the Penal Code?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 162 - Public servant taking gratification other than legal remuneration in respect of an official act.: Section 162 prescribes imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both for offering or taking gratification to influence a public servant. No minimum term is specified.
What are the maximum and minimum punishments for sexual harassment under the Penal Code?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 365B - Sexual harassment.: Section 365B provides for imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to five years, or with fine, or with both. No minimum term.
Primus inter pares?
According to Second Republican Constitution of Sri Lanka (1978): A PM is sometimes referred to as a primus inter pares – but the President is akin to that of a primus solus.
What are the maximum and minimum punishments for public servant framing incorrect document under the Penal Code?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 215 - Public servant framing incorrect record.: Section 215 prescribes imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both. No minimum punishment.
How elected?

According to Second Republican Constitution of Sri Lanka (1978): The President is selected by a separate election based on the system of absolute majority. The President is directly accountable to his electorate.
What is the punishment for adulteration of drugs?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 274 - Adulteration of drugs.: Section 274 punishes adulteration of drugs with noxious substance with imprisonment up to six months or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.
What is the punishment for screening offender from punishment?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 214 - Offering gift or restoration of property in consideration of screening offender.: Section 214 punishes screening offender with same punishment as harbouring.
What is a granted constitution, with Soulbury as example.

A constitution which is granted is one which has its legal origin in the form an enactment or authorization by some other supreme legislative body. Through a granted constitution only a very limited power is vested on the legislature. Eg: The Soulbury Constitution.
What is the punishment for dishonest misappropriation of property as a clerk or servant?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 392 - Criminal breach of trust by clerk or servant.: Section 392 punishes criminal breach by clerk or servant with imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
What are the maximum and minimum punishments for false statement on oath to public servant under the Penal Code?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 179 - False statement on oath to public servant.: Section 179 provides for imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine. No minimum term.
What is the punishment for electronic bigamy facilitation?
According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 496AA - Facilitation of bigamy by electronic means.: Section 496AA punishes electronic bigamy facilitation with imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
Define threatening any person to give false evidence in the Sri Lanka Penal Code.

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 194: Whoever threatens any person with any injury, with intent to induce such person to give false evidence in any stage of a judicial proceeding, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, or with fine, or with both.
How is disobedience to summons defined in the Sri Lanka Penal Code?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 174: Whoever, being legally bound to attend in person or by an agent at a certain place and time in obedience to a summons, notice, order, or proclamation proceeding from any public servant legally competent, as such public servant, to issue the same, intentionally omits to attend at that place or time, shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to one month, or with fine which may extend to five hundred rupees, or with both.
What power does president exercise?

According to Second Republican Constitution of Sri Lanka (1978), Article 4(b): The President so elected shall exercise the executive power of the people. “The executive power of the People, including the defence of Sri Lanka, shall be exercised by the President of the Republic elected by the People.” [Article 4(b)]
How is counterfeiting a property-mark used by a public officer defined in the Sri Lanka Penal Code?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 484: Whoever counterfeits any property-mark used by a public officer, or any mark used by a public officer to denote the manufacture, quality, strength, origin or purity of any goods, with intent to cause damage or injury to the public or to any person, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.
Discuss Prevention of Terrorism Bill on judicial power.

According to Prevention of Terrorism (Temporary Provisions) (Amendment) Bill: Clause 15A(1) of the Bill sought to empower the Minister to make order that a person be kept in custody of any authority which in effect meant that a person could be transferred from Judicial custody to ministerial custody. Argued that this violated Article 3 read with Article 4(c) of the constitution. The supreme court upholding this decision held that “ this constitutes an interference with a judicial order and is inconsistent with the provisions of Article 4(c) read with Article 3 of the Constitution and must therefore be passed by a 2/3rd Majority and approved by the people at a referendum as provided in Article 83...”
Personal liberty?
Article 13 sets out freedom from arbitrary arrest, guarantees him the protection of not being arrested on mere suspicion, detention, and punishment and prohibits retroactive penal legislation.
What in Visuvalingam v Liyanage?

According to Visuvalingam v Liyanage (1983) 1 SLR 203: With regards to whether the actions of the President can be challenged by a Court, the case of Visuvalingam v Liyanage (1983) 1 SLR 203 is instructive. The Supreme Court, with Chief Justice Neville Samarakoon stated the following: ‘Actions of the executive are not above the law and certainly can be questioned in a court of law.  Article 35 of the Constitution provides only for the personal immunity of the President during his tenure of office from proceedings in any Court. The President cannot be summoned to Court to justify his actions. But that is a far cry from saying that the President’s acts cannot be examined by a court of law. Though the President is immune from proceedings in Court, a party who invokes the acts of the President in his support will have to bear the burden of demonstrating that such acts of the President are warranted by law; the seal of the President by itself will not be sufficient to bear that burden.’
What are the maximum and minimum punishments for making or possessing counterfeit seal for forgery under the Penal Code?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 470 - Making or possessing counterfeit seal with intent to commit forgery.: Section 470 punishes with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and fine. No minimum term.
Does the 13th Amendment restrict parliamentary supremacy?

According to 13th Amendment to the Constitution (1987); In Re Thirteenth Amendment (1987) 2 SLR 312: Does the 13th Amendment impose a restriction on the legislative supremacy of the Parliament? Article 75 “Parliament shall have the power to make laws, including laws having retrospective effect…” The 13th Amendment introduced 3 lists; Reserved List [Article 154G (7)] A provincial Council has no power to make statutes on any matter set out in List II of the Ninth Schedule (Reserved List) Exclusively for Central Parliament Provincial Council List [Article 154G (1)] Every Provincial Council may, subject to the provisions of the Constitution, make statutes applicable to the Province for which is established, with respect to any matter set out in List I of the Ninth Schedule (Provincial Council List) Only regarding matters pertaining to their area (within its geographical boundary) [Article 154G (3)] This article sets out the special procedure to be followed by Parliament when making laws in respect of the Provincial Council list. [Article 154G (4)] Parliament can make law on any matter set out in the Provincial Council List where one or more provincial Councils request Parliament by resolution. Concurrent List [Article 154G (5)] Both the Parliament and the Provincial council can legislate after consultations (with each other). [Article 154G (6)] In the case of any conflict between Provincial Statute and an Act of Parliament, the Act prevails and the Provincial statute shall be void to the extent of inconsistency. [Article 154G (9)] If the Law existed prior to the 13th Amendment, this Law remains suspended and inoperative within the province so long as the statute id in force unless the Parliament decides contrary by resolution. After which the Act is valid It is therefore noted that some amount of legislative power is granted to the Provincial Councils by the 13th Amendment.
What powers in sovereignty under 1972?
According to First Republican Constitution of Sri Lanka (1972): Sovereignty contained only the government powers; Legislative, executive and Judiciary.
What are the maximum and minimum punishments for cruelty to children under the Penal Code?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 308A - Cruelty to children.: Section 308A punishes cruelty to children with rigorous imprisonment for a term not less than two years and not exceeding ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
What is executive power?
According to Second Republican Constitution of Sri Lanka (1978): Executive power is the power to execute the business of government on the basis of prerogative powers; it is always an active power.
What are the maximum and minimum punishments for personating a juror under the Penal Code?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 227A - Personating a juror.: Section 227A punishes with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both. No minimum term.
What is the punishment for voluntarily causing grievous hurt by dangerous weapons?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 326 - Voluntarily causing grievous hurt by dangerous weapons or means.: Section 326 punishes grievous hurt by dangerous means with imprisonment for life or up to ten years and fine.
What are the maximum and minimum punishments for hiring child to commit offence under the Penal Code?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 360B - Hiring child to commit offence.: Section 360B punishes with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both. No minimum term.
What are the maximum and minimum punishments for criminal intimidation to cause alarm under the Penal Code?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 481 - Criminal intimidation.: Section 481 provides for imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both. No minimum term.
17th Amendment?

17th Amendment: Passed in 2001, reduced presidential power by establishing independent commissions. 18th Amendment: Passed in 2010, increased presidential power by removing term limits and replacing Constitutional Council. 19th Amendment: Passed in 2015, reduced presidential power again, introduced right to information, term limits.
What are the maximum and minimum punishments for imputing unchastity under the Penal Code?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 485 - Imputation of unchastity to a woman.: Section 485 provides for simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both. No minimum punishment.
Discuss In Re 19th Amendment on executive power.

According to In Re 19th Amendment to the Constitution (2002) 3 SLR 85: Dissolution of parliament is a component of executive power of the people to be exercised by the president for the people. It cannot alienated in the sense of being transferred, relinquished or removed from where it lies in terms of Article 70(1) of the constitution. The final say even in the situation referred to in Article 70(a) to (c) remains with the President. Therefore, the amendments contained in clause 4 and 5 of the Bill constitute an alienation of executive power inconsistent with Article 3 read with Article 4 of the constitution and require to be passed by the special majority required under Article 84(2) and approved by the people at a referendum by virtue of the provisions of Article 83.
What is the punishment for rash act in public conveyance?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 279 - Rash driving or riding on public way.: Section 279 punishes rash driving with imprisonment up to six months or fine up to one thousand rupees, or both.
Explain the historical advocacy and reasons for introducing the executive presidential system in Sri Lanka as per the 1978 Constitution.

According to Second Republican Constitution of Sri Lanka (1978): J.R. Jayewardene advocated the executive presidential system as long ago as 1966, with R. Premadasa supporting the proposal during the 1970-72 Constituent Assembly era. Little would they have known that they both would be nationally elected Presidents. It was JR’s firm belief that economic development was necessary for democracy and it could not be achieved without a good deal of decisive government action. A.J. Wilson, who was an admirer of Jayewardene, stated that the two main reasons for the executive presidency were: a) the need for stability, and b) the empowerment of minorities.
What are the maximum and minimum punishments for dowry prohibition violation under the Penal Code?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 496B - Dowry prohibition.: Section 496B punishes violation of dowry prohibition with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine. No minimum.
What is the punishment for electronic criminal breach of trust facilitation?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 389A - Facilitation of criminal breach of trust by electronic means.: Section 389A punishes electronic facilitation of criminal breach with imprisonment up to three years or fine, or both.
Define attempt to commit culpable homicide in the Sri Lanka Penal Code.

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 298: Whoever attempts to commit culpable homicide, and in such attempt does any act under such circumstances that if he by that act caused death he would be guilty of culpable homicide, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both; and if hurt is caused to any person thereby, the offender shall be liable either to imprisonment for life or to such punishment as is hereinbefore mentioned.
What is non-refoulment?

According to Declaration on Upholding Human Rights and the Rule of Law in Combating Terrorism: 10. Non – Refoulment - States may not expel, return, transfer or extradite a person suspected or convicted of acts of terrorism to a state where there is a risk that the person would be subjected to a serious violation of human rights including cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment, enforced disappearance or extrajudicial execution.
Address and policy?

According to Second Republican Constitution of Sri Lanka (1978): When in Parliament, the President can address the assembly, deliver the statement of government policy at the commencement of the new session.
What are the maximum and minimum punishments for voluntarily causing hurt to extort property under the Penal Code?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 325 - Voluntarily causing hurt to extort property.: Section 325 punishes with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine. No minimum punishment.
What is the punishment for theft in a dwelling house?
According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 369 - Theft in dwelling house, etc.: Section 369 punishes theft in dwelling house with imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
What is the punishment for defiling place of worship with intent to insult religion?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 290 - Defiling place of worship with intent to insult the religion of any class.: Section 290 punishes defiling place of worship with imprisonment up to two years or fine, or both.
What is Article 13(6)?

According to Second Republican Constitution of Sri Lanka (1978), Article 13(6): Prohibits the creation of offences with retrospective effect as well as retrospective enhancement of punishment (however, this does not cover acts or omissions which are criminal according to general principles of International law).
What is the punishment for criminal breach of trust by public servant?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 409 - Criminal breach of trust by public servant.: Section 409 punishes criminal breach by public servant with imprisonment for life or up to ten years and fine.
What is equality before the law?

According to Second Republican Constitution of Sri Lanka (1978), Article 12(1): Equality before the law (negative aspect) Requires that the law of the land be enforced against all persons equally without any distinction made on any ground whatsoever.
How is good faith opinion on merits of public performance defined in the Sri Lanka Penal Code?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 479, Third Exception: It is not defamation to express in good faith any opinion respecting the merits of any performance submitted by any person to the judgment of the public, or respecting the character of the author so far as his character appears in such performance and no further, or respecting the character of the painter, sculptor, musician, or other artist so far as his character appears in his work and no further.
What is the punishment for belonging to a gang of dacoits?
According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 383 - Belonging to gang of dacoits.: Section 383 punishes belonging to a gang of dacoits with rigorous imprisonment up to seven years and fine.
How is fraudulent removal or concealment of property defined in the Sri Lanka Penal Code?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 424: Whoever dishonestly or fraudulently conceals, removes, or transfers any property, knowing that such property has been attached or is intended to be attached by a Court of Justice, or is so disposed of as to prevent it from being taken in execution of a decree, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
Is cabinet collegial?
According to Second Republican Constitution of Sri Lanka (1978): As the President is dominant, writers suggest that the Cabinet is less collegial but a support team.
What is the definition of the state according to Harold Laski?

‘The State’, according to Harold Laski in a Grammar of Politics “is a temporal society divided into government and subject claiming within its allotted physical area, a supremacy over all other institutions. It is in fact the final legal repository of the social will…”
What is omission to assist public servant when bound by law to give assistance in the Sri Lanka Penal Code?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 187: Whoever, being legally bound to give any notice or to furnish information on any subject to any public servant, as such, intentionally omits to give such notice or to furnish such information in the manner and at the time required by law, shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to one month, or with fine which may extend to two hundred rupees, or with both.
What is the punishment for disturbing religious assembly?
According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 290 - Disturbing religious assembly.: Section 290 punishes disturbing religious assembly with imprisonment up to one year or fine, or both.
What is the punishment for public servant unlawfully engaging in trade?
According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 168 - Public servant unlawfully engaging in trade.: Section 168 punishes public servant trading with imprisonment up to one year or fine, or both.
What are the maximum and minimum punishments for escape from custody under the Penal Code?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 217 - Escape from confinement.: Section 217 provides for imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both. No minimum punishment.
What is the operation of a constitution showing rigidity or flexibility?

The operation of a constitution shows that, what really gives it rigidity or flexibility is attributed to political and psychological factors such as the temperament and character of those operating the constitution concerned.
Define taking gift to screen an offender from punishment in the Sri Lanka Penal Code.

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 110: Whoever accepts or agrees to accept any gratification for himself or any other person, or any restitution of property to himself or any other person, in consideration of his screening any offender from punishment, or of his omitting to do what is in his power to do to bring an offender to justice, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, or with fine, or with both.
What is a rigid constitution?

According to Second Republican Constitution of Sri Lanka (1978), Article 82, Article 83: A rigid constitution is one under which the fundamental laws cannot be altered in the same manner as ordinary laws or cannot be altered at all. Rigid constitutions can be further classified as follows: i. Constitutions in which the special amending procedure is within the sole power of the legislature. (Eg: India) ii. Constitutions which require a special amending procedure to brought in by an external source. (Eg: Switzerland). The second Republican Constitution of Sri Lanka presents a hybrid of (i) and (ii). While certain provisions can be amended in parliament by adopting the special procedure laid down in the constitution, certain other provisions can be altered only by seeking a vote at a referendum.
Written and unwritten constitutions?

A constitution is said to be written where the rules relating to the organs of government are laid down in a formal document containing special legal sanctity. Eg USA, India, Sri Lanka (Soulbury, 1972 & 1978). Jurists have stated that a written constitution is the final outcome of a constituent assembly. In an unwritten Constitution, the rules relating to the organs of government are not formally laid down in a specific document, but have evolved through constitutional conventions. Eg: Britain (Possess an unwritten constitution and hence the rules relevant to the government are found in statutes such as the Bill of Rights and Act of Settlement).
What are the maximum and minimum punishments for importing counterfeit coin under the Penal Code?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 233 - Import or export of counterfeit coin.: Section 233 provides for imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine. No minimum term.
What is the punishment for electronic unnatural offence facilitation?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 365AA - Facilitation of unnatural offence by electronic means.: Section 365AA punishes electronic facilitation of unnatural offence with imprisonment up to ten years and fine.
Does president continue?

According to Second Republican Constitution of Sri Lanka (1978): Notwithstanding the dissolution of the parliament, the President continues to hold office. He is able to perform the functions of the cabinet until the parliament is reassembled.
What is the punishment for abetment of mutiny if not committed?
According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 132A - Abetment of mutiny if mutiny not committed.: Section 132A punishes abetment of uncommitted mutiny with imprisonment up to two years and fine.
How is harm to a person's reputation defined in defamation under the Sri Lanka Penal Code?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 479, Explanation 4: No imputation is said to harm a person's reputation, unless that imputation directly or indirectly, in the estimation of others, lowers the moral or intellectual character of that person, or lowers the character of that person in respect of his caste or of his calling, or lowers the credit of that person, or causes it to be believed that the body of that person is in a loathsome state or in a state generally considered as disgraceful.
What are the maximum and minimum punishments for child pornography under the Penal Code?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 285B - Child pornography.: Section 285B punishes child pornography with rigorous imprisonment for a term not less than two years and not exceeding ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
What are the maximum and minimum punishments for unnatural offences under the Penal Code?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 365A - Unnatural offences.: Section 365A punishes with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and fine. No minimum term.
What are the maximum and minimum punishments for putting in fear to commit extortion under the Penal Code?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 369 - Putting person in fear of injury in order to commit extortion.: Section 369 prescribes imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both. No minimum punishment.
What did Juan Linz say on presidential system?

According to Juan Linz: Juan Linz states that the presidential system encourages a personalized style of politics that favours charismatic politicians and populists and that such is at odds with the basic norms of constitutionalism.
What are the maximum and minimum punishments for counterfeiting election seal under the Penal Code?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 169M - Counterfeiting election seal.: Section 169M punishes with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both. No minimum term.
What is the immunity of the president?

According to Second Republican Constitution of Sri Lanka (1978), Article 35: Article 35(1) Confers on the President immunity from judicial proceedings. “While any person holds office as President of the Republic of Sri Lanka, no civil or criminal proceedings shall be instituted or continued against the President in respect of anything done or omitted to be done by the President, either in his official or private capacity: Provided that nothing in this paragraph shall be read and construed as restricting the right of any person to make an application under Article 126 against the Attorney-General, in respect of anything done or omitted to be done by the President, in his official capacity: Provided further that the Supreme Court shall have no jurisdiction to pronounce upon the exercise of the powers of the President under Article 33(2)(g)..” The SC has decided many cases regarding Article 35(1). Mallikarachchi v AG (1985) 1 SLR 74 “The rationale of this principle is that persons occupying such high office should not be amenable to the Jurisdiction of any but the representatives of the people, by whom he might be impeached and be removed from office and that once he has ceased to hold office, he may be held accountable in proceedings in the ordinary court of law.” Kumaratunge ve Jayakody and another (1985) 2 SLR 124 “ Article 35 gives blanket immunity to the president from proceedings of any kind whatsoever instituted or continued against him in any court of law…” Article 35(3) Immunity does not apply in the capacity of a Minister (Respondent would then be the AG) Visuwalingham and Others v Liayanage and Otehrs (183) 1 SLR 203 - SC tried to dilute the immunity enjoyed by the president. (Immunity for the “office” POF president and not the “doer” of the Act). “ Actions of the executive are not above the law and certainly can be questioned by a Court of Law. Article 35 provides only for the personal immunity of the president during the tenure of his office from proceedings in any court. Karunatilleke v Dissanayake (1999) 1 SLR 157 - Further clarified that which was discussed in the previous case. “… It imposes no bar whatsoever on proceedings (a) against him when he is no longer in office… Immunity is a shield for the doer, not for the act.” Senarath v Chandraratne, Commissioner of Excise and Others (1995) 1 SLR 209 - President’s acts were relied on by the commissioner of Excise to justify his acts. “in the instant case the petitioner has not filed proceedings in a court seeking relief against the President. The Respondents to the application are all officials. Relief has been sought against the officials only.” Senarath and others v Kumaratunga and Others [SC FR 503/2005]. - The only case where a person instituted action against a president after she left office.
What are the maximum and minimum punishments for malignant act to spread infection under the Penal Code?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 268 - Malignant act likely to spread infection.: Section 268 punishes with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both. No minimum punishment.

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 504B - Facilitation of provoke breach insult by electronic means.: Section 504B punishes electronic facilitation of provoke breach insult with imprisonment up to two years or fine, or both.
What impeachment?

According to Second Republican Constitution of Sri Lanka (1978), Article 38: Whilst the President does not owe his position to Parliament, yet removal is at the behest of Parliament. Article 38 specifies the mechanics of impeachment.
What Article 70 on summon etc?

According to Second Republican Constitution of Sri Lanka (1978), Article 70: Under Article 70, the President is empowered to summon, prorogue and dissolve Parliament. He can prorogue Parliament at any time. However, he cannot dissolve a parliament until a period of two years and six months elapse from its first meeting, unless the Parliament by resolution so requests an early prorogation.
What is discrimination in equality?

According to Second Republican Constitution of Sri Lanka (1978), Article 12(1); Perera v Jayawickrama (1985) 1 SLR 285@297: What the equality provision prohibits is ‘discrimination’, i.e. treatment of a person in a manner prejudicial to him as compared to another person in similar circumstances. It does not prohibit ‘reasonable classification’ (grouping of a person or things based on some real and substantive distinction bearing a just and reasonable relation to the object sought to be attained). “Before a person can claim to be discriminated against another, he must show that the other person was similarly situated or equally circumstanced; he must, make out that , not only had he been treated differently from others, but that he had been treated from persons similarly placed without any reasonable basis and such differentiated treatment is unjustifiably made” (Perera v Jayawickrama (1985) 1 SLR 285@297)
Explain supremacy of parliament under 1972 Constitution.

According to First Republican Constitution of Sri Lanka (1972), Articles 5, 44, 45, 48, 51, 52, 55: Article 5 NSA exercises the legislative power of the people Section 44 “the legislative power of the NSA is supreme and includes the power, a) To repeal or amend the constitution as a whole or in any part, and b) To enact a new constitution to replace the constitution ... Section 51(5) Repeal, replacement or amendment of the constitution with the vote of two thirds of the whole number of members of the Assembly (including those not present) Section 48(1) Retrospective operation of any or all of the provisions of law Section 52(1) Enact any law which is inconsistent with any provision in the constitution with a vote of two thirds of the whole number of members of the Assembly (including those not present). No provision similar to section 29(2) of the Soulbury constitution. Proviso to section 44 “Provided that such power shall not include the power, i. To suspend the operation of the constitution or any part thereof; and ii. To repeal the constitution as a whole without enacting a new constitution to replace it.”
Explain rule of law.

According to Second Republican Constitution of Sri Lanka (1978): The concept of ROL is not only of great antiquity but also one of the predominant concepts of constitutionalism. In essence, the concept suggests that society should be governed by law alone and all must be equally subjected to the law. For a government to be conducted under the law it is essential that there are both judicial and parliamentary procedures which ensure that the government only uses those powers that have been conferred on them and the government is accountable to the people through Parliament. But if the executive have excess power over proceedings of Parliament and also the ability to influence the legislature and Judiciary, such powers derogate from Separation of Powers. The Judiciary though separate from legislature constitutionally, is subordinate to the law making Parliament. The intentions of the Parliament was, as always to adhere to the ROL is borne in mind by the Judges in deciding FR cases. Judges or no judicial office can declare an Act of Parliament invalid. Validity of an Act passed by the legislature is unchallengeable and Parliament at any given time can overturn a judicial decision by enacting a new Act because Parliament has the ultimate power to make laws. Thus we can argue that ROL cannot stand alone without Constitutionalism and vice versa! For the ROL to be adhered to there should be a separation between the law makers and law enforcement. Thus constitutionalism demands a clearly defined separation of the two concepts, sovereignty and the government. How the FRs are protected in the constitution by itself is of utmost importance. ROL demands interpretation of Acts of parliament bearing in mind the intentions of parliament, but the constitutional restrictions placed on the government power also has to be observed as a part of ROL and to uphold constitutionalism. In safeguarding FRs, the idea of constitutionalism has played a major role in SL because FRs are both written and entrenched. SL has emerged successfully with the concept of constitutionalism and with its practical plausibility. The written constitution adds value in terms of writtenness and entrenchment of FR and entrenchment of FR and extends to other important provisions of the constitution. The issue of ROL in its ability to set the restrictions upon the Freedoms and rights of individuals is remedied by the Sri Lankan constitution by clearly enumerating article 15 (Restriction of FRs) SL maintains its parliamentary sovereignty by Article 75 and 83 while not compromising on the supremacy of the constitution.
What is the punishment for threatening public servant with injury?
According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 189 - Threat of injury to public servant.: Section 189 punishes threat to public servant with imprisonment up to two years or fine, or both.
What are the maximum and minimum punishments for sale of noxious food under the Penal Code?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 271 - Sale of noxious food or drink.: Section 271 provides for imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to one thousand rupees, or with both. No minimum punishment.
What is Article 12(1)?
According to Second Republican Constitution of Sri Lanka (1978), Article 12(1): All persons are equal before the law and are entitled to the equal protection of the law.
What are the maximum and minimum punishments for culpable homicide under the Penal Code?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 295 - Culpable homicide.: Section 295 punishes culpable homicide with imprisonment for life, or imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine. Minimum is the alternative.
Define lurking house-trespass in the Sri Lanka Penal Code.

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 440: Whoever commits house-trespass having taken precautions to conceal such house-trespass from some person who has a right to exclude or eject the trespasser from the building, tent or vessel which is the subject of the house-trespass, is said to commit 'lurking house-trespass'.
What are the maximum and minimum punishments for importing counterfeit coin under the Penal Code?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 233 - Import or export of counterfeit coin.: Section 233 provides for imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and fine. No minimum term.
What is Article 33A on president?

According to Second Republican Constitution of Sri Lanka (1978), Article 33A: “to do all such acts and things, not inconsistent with the provisions of the Constitution or written law, as by international law, custom or usage the President is authorized or required to do.”
Define counterfeiting of coin in the Sri Lanka Penal Code.
According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 218: Whoever counterfeits or knowingly performs any part of the process of counterfeiting any coin.
What is the nature of constitutional law as defined in the document?

The Constitutional law of a state has been defined as “the law relating to the constitution of a state”. The definition is wide enough to include the study of matters that are of constitutional importance to a country, such as the historical, political and philosophical foundations of the constitution.
What in crisis?
According to Second Republican Constitution of Sri Lanka (1978): Whenever a serious issue arises, the President is the center of consultation and decision making.
What prerogative not specified?

According to Second Republican Constitution of Sri Lanka (1978): The extent of his prerogative such as giving orders to departmental heads, removing them, commanding the military etc. are not specified, highlighting the importance of the prerogative power.
Explain the nature of constitutional law.

The Constitutional law of a state has been defined as “the law relating to the constitution of a state”. The definition is wide enough to include the study of matters that are of constitutional importance to a country, such as the historical, political and philosophical foundations of the constitution.
Define insult with intent to provoke a breach of the peace in the Sri Lanka Penal Code.

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 485: Whoever intentionally insults, and thereby disturbs the public peace, or with intent to provoke a breach of the peace, or to provoke any other person to commit an offence, shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
Discuss cases on directive principles.

According to Seneviratne and another v UGC and another (1978-79-80) 1 SLR 182; In Re thirteenth Amendment to the Constitution and the Provincial Council Bills (1987) 2 SKR 312; Vadivelu v OIC , Sithambarapura Regional Camp Police Post, Vavuniya and Others (2002) 3 SLR 146; Mediwake and Others v Dayananda Disanayke, Commissioner of Elections and Others (2001) 1 SLR 177; Weerawansa v The AG (2000) 1 SLR 409: Seneviratne and another v UGC and another (1978-79-80) 1 SLR 182 - “… It has been said that that the Directive Principles are in the nature of an instrument of instructions which both the Legislature and executive must respect and follow.” In Re thirteenth Amendment to the Constitution and the Provincial Council Bills (1987) 2 SKR 312 - “… The Directive principles require to be implemented by legislation”. Vadivelu v OIC , Sithambarapura Regional Camp Police Post, Vavuniya and Others (2002) 3 SLR 146 - “ … It is true that the Directive Principles of State Policy do not confer or impose legal rights and obligations and are not enforceable in any Court, but that does not mean that the Judiciary is bound to ignore them.” Mediwake and Others v Dayananda Disanayke, Commissioner of Elections and Others (2001) 1 SLR 177 - “… Article 27(15) requires the state endeavor to foster respect for international law and treaty obligations in dealings among nations”. Weerawansa v The AG (2000) 1 SLR 409 - Artivle 27(15) was extensively discussed yet again.
How did British parliament grow?

According to Magna Carta (1215); Case of Proclamation (1610); Bill of Rights (1689): In Britain, the transformation of legislative power from an all powerful Monarch to the British Parliament took place over a period of time. Growth of the powers of the British Parliament took place through a series of events including Magna Carta (1215) Case of Proclamation (1610) Bill of Rights (1689)
What are the maximum and minimum punishments for rash driving endangering life under the Penal Code?

According to Penal Code of Sri Lanka, Section 277A - Rash driving or riding on public way.: Section 277A provides for imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine up to one thousand rupees, or with both. No minimum term.
